title: Operation Midland report: the litany of failures that left Scotland Yard's reputation in tatters
text:
After almost 400 pages listing blunder after blunder, the reputation of the Metropolitan Police lay in tatters.

A review of the force’s 16 month investigation into a Westminster paedophile ring, codenamed Operation Midland, has shown how officers believed the stories of fantasist Carl Beech even as the evidence proved that he was lying.

The investigation ventured into the “hysterical and disproportionate” and the names of “men of outstanding reputation” including a former Prime Minister, a former Home Secretary and the former head of the Armed Forces were unnecessarily dragged through the mud.

The full scale of the incompetence can be detailed for the first time as the review by retired High Court judge Sir Richard Henriques is published unredacted for the first time after three years of pressure.

Police blunders

There were 43 key failings by officers investigating the “implausible” and inconsistent claims which led to the investigation carrying on ten months longer than it could have, Sir Richard has concluded.

After wrongly accepting the fantasist a truthful witness from the outset, “poor judgment” from officers and an “unwarranted and disproportionate belief” in what Beech was saying led to failures to question him on numerous inconsistencies.

The review details a number of delays in the case which meant that witness statements which proved the allegations were a tissue of lies were not taken.
